reviews.name: margatemensch2016
reviews.title: One Fine Day Perusing Quality Art
reviews.comment:
On a hot July Thursday,I spent a delightful day perusing its fine samples of paintings and Art produced by European Painters.European favorites that day were Master of Santa Maria De La Hoz'"Saint john the Baptist"(Spanish Renaissance),Polidoro di Bartolomeo's"Crucifixion with Saints"(Italian Renaissance),Pier Francesco Foschi's"Young Man Weaving Wreath of Flowers"(High italian Renaissance),Pieter Breughel the Younger's"Maypole Dance"(Flemish Baroque),Melchior D'Hondecoeter's"Birds in Landscape"(Dutch Master),Charles Lebrun's tapestry."Queens of Persia At Foot of Alexander The Great"(18th Century),Gian Paolo Paninni's"Capriccio with Roman Ruins"(Italian Neoclassical),Etienne De Lavalle's"Anacreon,Eros,Sappho,and Female Dancer"(18th French),Jean Leon Gerome's"Christian's Last Prayer"(French Naturalism)Narcise De La Pena's"Forest Pool"(French Barbizon),and Armand Guillaumin's"Le Maison Nannette a Crozant"(French Expressionism).
I also savored their fine samples of American Paintings and Art.Personal American favorites that day included John Copley's"John,2nd Viscount"(tip top Mannerism),Theodore Butler's"Honfleur"(quality Pointillism),Ralph Blakelock's"Silvery Night",Birger Sandzen's"2 Pines"(American Expressionism),Conrad Buff's"Canyonlands"(American Regionalism),Thomas Moran's"Wilhelmina Pass,Weber Canyon,Utah",and Louise Farnsworth's"Blue Shadows"(American Regionalism by Utah Painter).
I also relished their fine collection of Antiquities from India such as;North India "Vishnu and Avatars"(12th Century Varanasi)"Shiva With Parvati(10th Century),and "Shiva,Lord of Dance".I also enjoyed studying their Antiquities from China(Guan Yin,Ming)
I spent a very productive day at one of the better university art museums in this region of the United States..I also liked the ambience of this art museum.

reviews.name: Corsican in America
reviews.title: Exhibition Black Refractions
reviews.comment:
Black Refractions: Highlights from The Studio Museum in Harlem:
Very well managed, and pretty accessible.
The main message and historical background is conveyed here, and a lot of very interesting pieces.
The permanent collection is limited but again a few very interesting pieces.
A lovely experience over a couple of hours, maybe 3.
Nice gift shop with a few books about the black American culture and its “contre culture” too, I learnt a lot.

reviews.name: Angie L
reviews.title: Art with lots of giggling
reviews.comment:
Wanting to take my kids to a museum during covid has been a challenge. With this museum being open, affordable, and showing a few pieces from the Smithsonian; I thought it would be a good fit for my family.
3/4 of the art work showed nudity or semi nudity. So having children meant constant giggling or covering of eyes.
I was aware from their website that this museum believes in showing all sorts of art work. But every corner we turned showed more and more nudity work.
So I suggest to go elsewhere if that’s not your thing.

reviews.name: Micosay
reviews.title: Beautiful location
reviews.comment: Enjoyed all we saw. Registrar is great and very knowledgeable. Getting there is a little complicated.

reviews.name: Callisto S
reviews.title: Small collection, but nice museum
reviews.comment: We were able to comfortably go through the museum’s exhibits in just a couple of hours. The museum has a nice feel. Their collection touches on a wide variety of topics. We especially enjoyed the very ancient artifacts and works from Mexico and Central America, and more recent tribal works from Indonesia. They also have a couple of interesting 18th-century paintings with musical iconography.

reviews.name: LodiWineBob
reviews.title: Superb and Surprising
reviews.comment:
Incredibly impressed by this museum. Wide variety of art from around the world tastefully and professionally displayed and curated.
On the University of Utah campus which is also beautiful.
Very nice gift shop and small but seemingly popular cafe.

reviews.name: Claudia O
reviews.title: Beautiful, exquisite museum.
reviews.comment: They have art from all times and all over the world. You'll find Renaissance, religious art, modern art, art from Asia, Africa, Central America. I liked the art from Central America of course because I'm from there; also the one from China and Egypt. I'll go again on the first Wednesday of November because it's free. The floors are wooden. This place is so exquisite. Only allowed to take pictures without flash so be careful because it's art and art is beautiful and important. U of U students enter for free with their ID but I'm a mother.

reviews.name: Kevin W
reviews.title: Very Enjoyable and Worth a Visit
reviews.comment: My wife is the artist. We go to a lot of museums. We spent a good two hours here. Facility and overall environment of UMFA was wonderful. Two stories, with elevator. Great cafe and gift shop. Art included Asian, Pacific, African, Europe, American and more. Parking is free.

reviews.name: Peter P
reviews.title: Very Interesting Museum and a Beautiful Building: Well Worth the Visit
reviews.comment:
Okay, it is not the Metropolitan Museum or the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, but the UMFA is well worth the visit: there are some truly wonderful works of art on the one hand, and on the other the less than wonderful are deeply instructive. Signature, lighting, and installation are outstanding.
The small collections of objects from around the world are fascinating, and many of these objects are thrilling masterpieces.
The building itself is a massive airy sculpture.

reviews.name: dianaelms
reviews.title: Not impressed
reviews.comment: Not a great bang for the buck (overpriced) and I found all of the exhibits very limited. I can think of many art museums - even artisans at local framers' markets - that have more to offer in way of diversity and talent.

reviews.name: kaufmansn
reviews.title: Great collection!
reviews.comment: I was pleasantly surprised at the breadth of artworks in their collection! The staff is amazing, and the exhibits well displayed.

reviews.name: RNatha
reviews.title: Good general collection with interesting special exhibits
reviews.comment: For visitors, its special collections that might make a visit worthwhile. The permanent collection is nicely broad but not deep. Access by car or light rail is convenient, and parking is easy.

reviews.name: epicure5
reviews.title: Beautiful renovation!
reviews.comment: I visited Utah Museum of Fine Arts after it reopened after an extensive renovation, and it was very impressive indeed! Everything looks more refined and the art collection seems more varied and abundant. I would highly recommend it!

reviews.name: HoleySneakers
reviews.title: Like a Sampler Box of Good Candy
reviews.comment: The museum, located on the campus of the University of Utah, is worth the trip if you really enjoy art museums, but it does have some limitations. The collection is small but organized in such a way that is clearly intent to be instructional, inviting you to compare and contrast art from various parts of the world. It's a pleasant experience, but with only one or two "wow" moments in the collection. My real disappointment was in the tiny representation artists from Utah, or the Southwestern states - of which there are many good ones, and this would be a great showcase for them.

reviews.name: GEORGE H
reviews.title: Surprisingly good!
reviews.comment: Look I hate to admit thst anything on the campus of this mist hated school,is decent/worthwhile. If from BYU,you learn early and often,tomhatevall things U. My wife can't pass an art museum,so was dragged in,kicking snd screaming. . Great collections,great items,of all types and eras. Get the book by Will South in the gift shop . He now nlessess the Columbia art palace,with his expertise and person.

reviews.name: giovannonislc
reviews.title: Nice Museum and Worth The Trip
reviews.comment: Keep you eye open for certain exhibits as this museum is a local gem. It is currently being renovated so you'll have to catch it next time.

reviews.name: Susan S
reviews.title: Winter Art Fun
reviews.comment: My daughter and I enjoyed going to the museum on a cold winter day. We practically had the place to ourselves and it was fantastic!

reviews.name: cw99
reviews.title: arts and more arts
reviews.comment: Wonderful collection of fine arts, good location good access from local transportation free admission days check the local web site for info

reviews.name: SandDHwestchilt
reviews.title: Wedding venue
reviews.comment: Great venue for wedding plus able to wander around the art exhibition between wedding breakfast and evening reception

reviews.name: Jim L
reviews.title: Utah does have some fine arts; worth a visit
reviews.comment:
The UMFA is located on the University of Utah campus, readily accessible from downtown SLC via the TRAX red line (I used the Stadium stop but South Campus might be okay too). The museum is not huge but there is good space to accommodate touring exhibits plus the permanent collection. The latter focuses on painting but there is a small diversity including art from India, Pacific Islands, Egypt and some other parts of the world. Keep an eye out for some interesting contemporary exhibitions.
Full adult admission is $14 (discounts for seniors, students, etc). This is waived for North American Reciprocal Museums members. Also, general admission is free on the first Wednesdays and third Saturdays each month.

reviews.name: MikeNay
reviews.title: One of my favorite museums in Salt Lake
reviews.comment:
It's fun to go here on Free museum days (First Wednesdays and Third Saturdays). The third Saturdays also have special craft activities that you can participate in. They are aimed for families and children, but I often enjoy decorating clay plates, making a sculpture, etc as well. The museum staff is very friendly and explains the exhibits that are going on.
UMFA is well-curated, and even though it doesn't have any singular stand alone pieces, it is does have some beautiful works by famous artists such as Renoir and Singer-Sargent. These master works are combined with unique exhibits such as Mayan pottery, Spanish art, and an Egyptian sarcophagus room. It is well worth the low price of admission (especially on aforementioned free days).
Let it be said that I actually like the streamer room. Sure, it could probably be used for a lot more art in the large hall, and it isn't my favorite Feher piece, but it is pretty awesome to have a Feher piece at all. His work is certainly modern contemporary, which many people don't appreciate; that's fine. But he is one of the biggest names in the US of this generation, and the pink streamers are just another example of his simple trademark colorful design. For the people that don't appreciate the neon pink streamers - at least he didn't paint an entire city lot pink here as he did in New York.
There is also a small cafe in the front where you can get cookies, scones, and coffee, which is a great way to end your visit, or hang out while the kids are doing crafts or listening to stories.
The parking is the one thing that leaves more to be desired, but if you go on the weekend there is plenty of free parking since permits aren't enforced.

reviews.name: Keytothekingdom
reviews.title: nice outing
reviews.comment: This is not a large museum but I enjoyed my visit. The building itself is quite artistic with a huge flight of stairs and a room of ribbons hanging from the ceiling. Though I am not really that into art I liked it.

reviews.name: montanacwby
reviews.title: Art in Utah, Is Great
reviews.comment: Visited the Utah Fine Arts in September on a trip to Salt Lake City. They showing an exhibit on Rural English Landscape Painters which was outstanding. The whole arrangement was well done and spent an enjoyable afternoon there. The cafeteria there is also very pleasant so make a day of it and eat there. The physical facility is new and very large. Well worth your time. They had something for everyone

reviews.name: nonamesforme
reviews.title: Good collection
reviews.comment: A good and varied collection, including modern installations and historical western work. Fairly expensive entry fee. Free parking across the street.

reviews.name: Seattle J
reviews.title: Lovely small museum
reviews.comment: This museum was very peaceful on a hot August afternoon. There are lovely Old Master paintings and changing exhibits. The café was a nice place to relax with a cold drink.

reviews.name: Jennifer H
reviews.title: Lovely Gift shop and exhibits
reviews.comment: I went and spent about an hour. Which is about the right amount of time to spend. I would say no more than 90 minutes to see everything, read everything, and enjoy it. Admission is FREE for military! It is very quiet and the staff are helpful in directing you to different exhibits. There is a coffee snack shop inside as well as the gift shop.

reviews.name: mini
reviews.title: High Quality Art collection - Utah Museum of Fine Arts
reviews.comment:
I was impressed by the quality of this art museum on the University of Utah Campus. It is located in the Marcia and John Price Building on campus.
There are different sections in the gallery focusing on high quality art. Much of the art I knew and was impressed by the selection. They have art that focuses on the ancient and classical world, European and American masterworks, Asian art, art of Utah and the American West, and modern and contemporary art. My personal favorite was the art of Utah and the American West which had some stunning pieces.
There is an admission charge to the galleries.
One can park for free across the street from the Utah Museum of Fine Arts. The parking places are highlighted. One does need to register the car's license plate with the staff at the ticket desk at the gallery.

reviews.name: David B
reviews.title: A gem
reviews.comment:
This is a little, unexpected, gem. Unexpected, because I didn't think that there would be a museum in Salt Lake City with such high quality, and eclectic, collections. Gem, because it was really great.
From what I gather, the collections were largely the work of one person, who collected, and probably funded, the works on display, over a 20 year or so period.
The spaces for each exhibit are thoughtfully done. Some spaces are smaller than others, yet the displays are excellent, each piece well exhibited, and there is no feeling that works are crammed together.
Eclectic, because there is a huge range of exhibits, time periods, cultures. The Oceania Exhibit is small, with each piece of high quality, and some are simply about as good as they get. Ditto for the small exhibit of Buddhist art. The European paintings are excellent.
We planned on spending a couple of hours, and decided that we had to return for another visit. The museum merits minimally 3 hours.
This would be a great place for a kid to come to time and again, for short periods, to gain an understanding of the huge variety of cultures, periods and art, that the world has to offer. But, then, I am recalling my own early experiences, being taken to museums by my parents, where I was first exposed to the amazing variety of eras, cultures and art.
I should add that the staff are all very friendly, and made us feel welcomed.

reviews.name: Kari J
reviews.title: Small for a big city
reviews.comment:
Compared to other large city museums, this one is quite small. It's like the difference between going to a large grocery store and a convenience store. It has many categories of art, and some quality pieces, but just a few works in each section. Because of my poor sense of direction, I usually get lost in museums, but not this one. It's too small to get lost. I kept thinking, oh, that's all??
Many large museums have a children's section with hands on activities. This one didn't have a section like that.
It didn't have any regular daily tours either. And, the gift shop was small. So, as long as your expectations aren't too high, it's worth a couple hours.

reviews.name: KJT2010SJT
reviews.title: Enjoyable late morning
reviews.comment: The Museum opened at 11am on Sunday and there were very few people there, which allowed me to take my time at the exhibits that I most enjoyed. They offer a good mix of kinds of art, with a larger exhibit of natural Utah Indian artifacts.

reviews.name: Carol B
reviews.title: Well worth a visit
reviews.comment: The museum is located on the University campus, easy access from my downtown hotel via the SLC light rail system. The museum collection is interesting and varied and the exhibits are well curated.. The western art holdings in particular are excellent and varied, and the temporary exhibits were fantastic. Allow several hours. I had lunch at the museum cafe, delicious food and very friendly service, sat outside on the patio enjoying the mountain view. Great afternoon.

reviews.name: AnaBaile
reviews.title: A well-spent rainy Saturday afternoon
reviews.comment:
We have visited the UMFA a few times for special exhibits. Recently we had wanted to see the exhibit on the Bingham Canyon mine. It was very well done, including works from the museum's collection along with borrowed works from various sources. It piqued an interest in us about the process of curating a special exhibit.
I would suggest that parking could be better marked and explained. The building itself is great with easy access. There is a cafe available, although we did not eat there. We took a quick walk through the gift shop and found it to be very interesting, having some unique items for sale.
In addition to the Bingham mine exhibit, we perused the other works on display from the permanent collection. I agree that Salt Lake can and should have a more extensive art museum, but we are pleased with what we have. From the display of the history of the museum in the cafe it is clear that there are many works in storage that could be displayed were there more space and personnel, for instance it referred to a vast collection of Navajo weavings in the permanent collection. I want to see them! It also mentioned a collection of Chinese porcelain. What is in storage that was NOT mentioned!!!
As far as current displays, it seems rather heavy on South Pacific island works. We found the variety and quality of paintings from American and European artists to be quite broadly represented. The biggest surprise to me was a video performance work. Usually I scoff, since I consider myself somewhat of a provincial...but it actually captivated me as I took time to watch it. So the museum opened my mind to something new on a rainy Saturday. I loved that about it. Well worth the visit.

reviews.name: corvettegirl07
reviews.title: A great variety and changes often.
reviews.comment: This is a lovely museum that you can easily enjoy 1 1/2-2 hours exploring. I suggest taking one of the short tours to get you well acclimated and then take off on your own. They have a very nice cross selection of works and they rotate stored works to keep things changing. There is also a very nice restaurant and gift shop.

reviews.name: Ken B
reviews.title: Art on a modest scale
reviews.comment:
This is a modest-scale museum. The notable building is a fine display space. The permanent collection is limited in scope, but still manages to come up with some pleasant surprises. I found its array of American art to be quite serviceable. And the temporary exhibit on the Bingham Mine managed to be moving: and not just earth-moving! While a city the size of Salt Lake should certainly be able to support a greater arts effort, this is certainly a fine basis on which to build.
Note: calling this the greatest art museum in Utah is unfortunately very faint praise indeed.

reviews.name: smiles030
reviews.title: small museum
reviews.comment: the classical art and furniture is very nice but the collection is quite small. They had a nice exhibit about the Kennecott copper mine in Bingham which I had seen from the airplane. I had never seen such a large hole in the ground and had wondered what that was. This was the largest open pit copper mine in the world, visible from the space station but had a landslide in 2013 which forced them to close the mine. Nice little exhibit about the mine for those interested in such things. Took campus bus from here over to the museum of natural history for free.

reviews.name: Smillie-girl
reviews.title: Store and Cafe
reviews.comment: Unfortunately I did not have time for a full walk-about but I did spend time in the gift store and ate at the cafe. Both are excellent. Kudos to the buyer for the Museum store - saw several unique items and the manner of display made it fun to walk around. At the cafe I had the apple & brie baguette. YUM! I will definitely return - UMFA has late hours on WED for the business travellers.

reviews.name: Robert H
reviews.title: Good for Salt Lake but Still Average
reviews.comment: I have visited art museums around the world from the greatest to the smallest and would rate this one as mediocre for a city the size of Salt Lake. I lived in Salt Lake for eight years in the 1980s and concur with the opinion that the visual arts do not receive all that much attention. The permanent collection has a few nice works in several galleries painted in a garish orange that detracts from the paintings. The two special exhibits of note were paintings of the Great Salt Lake and contemporary prints. As an art aficionado, I spent a pleasant enough two hours but will repeat that a major urban center deserves a better art museum. The Swope Art Museum in Terre Haute, Indiana, a city with a metro population of 170,000, has a more impressive permanent collection. This museum certainly doesn't even come close to matching the Toledo Museum of Art in the city where I grew up.

reviews.name: Thompson1913
reviews.title: Great
reviews.comment: This is probly one of the greatest art museums in Utah. I loved it very much with all the great exhibitions.

reviews.name: JTravelBuddy
reviews.title: Nice Place for a Short Visit
reviews.comment: Price was right on Saturday (free). Native American subjects dominate, but overall it is well done. Building is beautiful.

reviews.name: FloridagirlP-cola
reviews.title: Expected more. Glad it was part of Connect PASS.
reviews.comment:
After reading that they had 18000 objects from around the world, I was disappointed. I went in the late morning and school groups at most exhibits. The exhibits on the Indians and Mummies (small) were interesting but no unforgettable pieces.
This museum is easy to walk to from the South Campus Trax station.

reviews.name: wbullseye
reviews.title: Small, but very well done
reviews.comment:
The Utah Museum of Fine Arts is located on the campus of the University of Utah in Salt Lake City. It is easy to find with signs along the main road. There is limited parking across the street from the museum as well as near the main entrance. Unless there is a football game, I wouldn't expect parking to be much of an issue however. The regular adult price for admission is $7, with discounts for senior citizens and children. Entrance is free for members of the military. However at $7 the museum is still worth it.
The museum is small but still provides an excellent selection of paintings and sculptures. Unlike many art museums in the US, this one actually has quality works by famous artists. You will not find any abstract or "art done by monkeys" here. They have temporary exhibits that rotate, but don't know how often.
They have a selection of Native American, US, Pacific Islands, ancient Egypt, Rome, and others in different rooms. While I was there they had a temporary exhibit titled: Bierstadt to Warhol: American Indians in the West, which was one of the better collections of art about the depiction of Native Americans I have seen at a small museum. The Native American There are signs that provide a background of the artist and the themes which help for those of us not familiar with them. There is also a free audio guide available, but didn't use it due to time restrictions.
The museum is open everyday except for Mondays and holidays. This makes it convenient for those looking for something to do on a Sunday. There is also a small cafe and store inside the museum. Photography is allowed throughout as long as you do not use a flash. I would definitely recommend the Utah Museum of Fine Arts. You can take as much time as necessary, but would plan on at least an hour or two.

reviews.name: Scott W
reviews.title: Nice place, but small
reviews.comment: Utah as a whole really needs a better museum. UMFA is a start and the one at BYU is OK, but where are the world class museums? Is utah just too small to justify a MOMA? also the parking situatino is abysmal

reviews.name: bikinchris
reviews.title: Well done
reviews.comment:
I stopped off to see the car display. They had one of the 6 Ford Daytona Coupes on display for a short while. They also had a couple of Dusenburgs.
We looked at a little of the art display and it was well chosen also.

reviews.name: Kirsten D
reviews.title: Campus Museum
reviews.comment: It wasn't too easy to find, the signage was quite small and confusing. The building is nice, with some permanent exhibits along with visiting ones. Rather small, but it is trying!

reviews.name: Artaficionado
reviews.title: Well, they try
reviews.comment: Unfortunately, there is not much of a visual arts tradition in Utah. This means that the museum lacks a base of cultured donors like the ones responsible for great museums in other provincial U.S. cities (Toledo, Ohio springs to mind, among others.) The quality of paintings and sculptures is low. The exhibits are good for elementary kids who need some art exposure. The curator does have a remedial plan, which is to concentrate on contemporary art. This is a good plan, because there is lots and lots of contemporary art to be found, and nobody knows if it is good or bad until the curator tells them.

reviews.name: BCowner55
reviews.title: Great art venue
reviews.comment: On the University of Utah campus with good parking and access. Exhibits are world class and change fairly frequently.

reviews.name: colony
reviews.title: Items being sold here were from other countries for the most part
reviews.comment: Beware of what you purchase here. You may think you are buying locally made Indian items and I found stickers on many pieces from Indonesia. I was very disappointed.

reviews.name: Travel-Bug-369
reviews.title: Good cafe at the museum too
reviews.comment: We actually went here with friends. One of our friends had donated art to this museum so we enjoyed a personal tour with the director and curator. Enjoyed a wonderful lunch after at the museum cafe.

reviews.name: Pnemiller
reviews.title: Very good art museum with striking interior on university campus
reviews.comment: This is a very good museum on the campus of the U. of Utah with free visitor parking. The interior design is spectacular with a center gallery that is 2 to 3 stories high and dramatic stairs leading to the 2nd floor. The art work is eclectic. Excellent American and Western art--Remington Bronco Buster, Dixon, Gilbert Stuart, Sargent, etc. European art was OK, but not great. Interesting temporary exhibits, especially Levitt photographs. This place is worth a viist and is is a member of the North American Reciprocal Museums (NARM) so it is free to members of other museums. There is also a small cafe.

reviews.name: lucy4414
reviews.title: Very enjoyable visit
reviews.comment: We wanted to go here when we visited Utah last year but the only day we had free then was a Monday and they don't open on Mondays. We had a voucher from a leaflet and were able to get one free entry so bith got in for $7. There were some great things to see with quite a range of stykes and cultures. The only bit we didn't enjoy was the Salt 1 exhibit - we couldn't see any artsitic value in a part-used toilet roll or an empty suitcase.

reviews.name: PULAOKHAO
reviews.title: Nice, moderate size museum
reviews.comment: This is a nice museum in a nice building; no flashy architecture by starchitect like gehry or libeskind but self-effacing building shows art very well. they do not have big name art like picasso or monet but small though comprehensive collection of european and american paintings as well as sculpture from asia and africa. full details on their website. i did not eat at their cafe. free parking. great place to spend a few hours if you like art museums.

reviews.name: perfectpug81
reviews.title: There are other things in utah besides LDS monuments
reviews.comment: This place is gorgeous, quiet, peaceful, and amazing. I think it is the perfect place to bring visitors from out of state, other reviews simply draw everyone to one main attraction, temple square. Dont get me wrong the flowers are beautiful there, but you would be missing out on culture and grace if you passed this place up. My advice, if you want true culture, dont miss out on this place.

reviews.name: utah_utes_9
reviews.title: Fun for locals, but if your visiting don't waste your time
reviews.comment: Don't get me wrong, I love the UMFA. I go the the University of Utah where it is located and its a great place to spend a quiet afternoon with a friend or two, but if you are visiting Salt Lake from out of state, it's not worth visiting. There are so many other things to do. My recommendations: visit temple square, the Tracey Aviary, LDS Conference Center, a Jazz Game or, of course, skiing!

reviews.name: harlyquin
reviews.title: University Museums are the only real museums in Utah.
reviews.comment:
One of the few examples of a real museum in Utah. A large collection of traditional paint-on-canvas, stone sculpture and metalwork art. Frequently features exhibits on loan from international collections, as well as contemporary contributions from local artists. Beautiful atmosphere for those expecting a quiet indoor experience, extremely low traffic most of the time. Stools available if you want to make a sketch or just sit and stare for a while (ask the admissions desk).
Good for ~ 1/2-6 hours depending on how you like to enjoy a museum, ( I spent 4 1/2 hours there because I like to sketch my favorite works).
cheep admission and open on saturdays.
